[[Image:PinkTaco.png|230px|right|alt=the words "pink taco" in pink, Gothic font]] '''Pink Taco''' is a restaurant in [[Los Angeles, California]]. It calls itself a chain, but currently only has one location open after previously having had several locations. It serves [[Mexican cuisine|Mexican food]]. The chain has earned notoriety due to its name, which is a [[slang]] term for the human [[vulva]].<ref name="CBS">{{cite news | title=Pink Taco Restaurant Name Causes Stir | date=May 16, 2006 | publisher=CBS | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2006/05/16/ap/strange/mainD8HKJQH81.shtml }} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> According to the restaurant, the name comes from a dish it serves.<ref>{{cite news | first=Lesley | last=Wright | title=Council gives OK for eatery liquor license | date=May 16, 2006| publisher=The Arizona Republic | url=http://www.azcentral.com/arizonarepublic/local/articles/0516netaco0516.html }}</ref>
== Locations == The first Pink Taco restaurant was opened in 1999 at the [[Hard Rock Hotel and Casino (Las Vegas)|Hard Rock Hotel and Casino]] in [[Las Vegas metropolitan area|Las Vegas]], Nevada.<ref>{{cite news | first = John | last = Katsilometes |title = Columnist John Katsilometes: Eateries need the right name | date = May 30, 1999 | publisher = Las Vegas Sun | url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/sunbin/stories/sun/1999/may/30/508860108.html?%5C%22pink%20taco&quot }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first = Megan | last = Finnerty |title = Suggestive name puts eatery, city at odds | date = April 22, 2006 | publisher = The Arizona Republic | url=http://www.azcentral.com/ent/dining/articles/0422pinktaco.html }}</ref> A second location in [[Scottsdale, Arizona]] met with [[Pink_Taco#Name_controversy|controversy]] and remained open for less than three years, between 2006 and 2009. A third location opened on June 28, 2007 in [[Century City, Los Angeles, California]].<ref name="OfficialWebsite">{{cite web | title=Pink Taco | url=http://www.pinktaco.com/ | accessdate=2007-06-08}}</ref> According to the restaurant's website, planned future locations include [[Hollywood, California]], [[San Diego, California]], and [[Miami, Florida]]. As of September 2010, only a single [[Los Angeles]], location, at [[Westfield Century City]] mall, was listed on that website.
== Name controversy == The name has caused controversy in [[Scottsdale, Arizona]], where the restaurant attempted to open a second location. In response, the city government received four [[emails]] complaining about the name. This generated a complaint from Mayor [[Mary Manross]] who said she was offended, although she did not see the name in a sexual way until the complaints were raised. She asked the owner to change the name, but he refused.<ref name="CBS" />
On May 15, 2006, the Scottsdale [[City Council]], by a unanimous vote, recommended the restaurant for a [[liquor]] [[license]] from the Arizona Department of Liquor Licenses and Control. One resident raised an objection at the meeting, saying the name "demeans and degrades women." The state agency said it had not received any complaints.<ref name="EastValleyTribune">{{cite news | first=Jonathan | last=Athens | title=Restaurant name spurs TV interest | date=May 18, 2006 | publisher=East Valley Tribune | url=http://www.eastvalleytribune.com/index.php?sty=65818}}</ref> The Scottsdale location closed its doors on April 1, 2009.{{Citation needed|date=August 2009}}
The restaurant quickly gained the attention of the media, and was soon contacted by representatives from ''[[The Daily Show with Jon Stewart]]'' and ''[[Mind of Mencia]]'' with requests for interviews, which were initially turned down.<ref name="EastValleyTribune" /> President and CEO [[Harry Morton]] appeared on the June 27, 2006 episode of ''The Daily Show'', which also featured a story on the controversy by reporter Ed Helms. During his interview, Morton explained that the name comes from a menu item, and that if the restaurant were truly "vagina-themed", there would be "vaginas all over the walls".<ref name=thedailyshow>''The Daily Show''. "Box Lunch." Ed Helms. Produced by Bronwen Epstein. Edited by Einar Westerlund.</ref> Pink Taco was also mentioned during the May 20, 2006 showing of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' as part of its "[[Weekend Update]]" skit.<ref name="SNL">{{Cite video | people=Fey, Tina (Cast), Amy Poehler (Cast) |date=2006 | title=Saturday Night Live | medium=TV-Series | location=United States | publisher=National Broadcasting Company}}</ref>
In August 2006, Morton announced a [[United States Dollar|$]]30 million bid for the naming rights to the [[Arizona Cardinals]]' new [[University of Phoenix Stadium|stadium]] in [[Glendale, Arizona]].<ref>Villalobos, Louie. "[http://www.azcentral.com/sports/special5/articles/0821stadium21-ON.html Pink Taco's owners make bid to name Cards stadium]." ''[[Arizona Republic]].'' August 21, 2006. Retrieved on August 21, 2006.</ref> The offer was rejected by the Cardinals, who dismissed the announcement as a joke and a publicity stunt. On September 28, 2006, Pink Taco launched a similar bid to rename the [[Louisiana Superdome]] in [[New Orleans]] to the "Pink Taco Dome". As the State of Louisiana owns the Superdome, any name change must be approved by the [[Louisiana State Legislature]].<ref>Mackel, Fletcher. "[http://news.yahoo.com/s/wdsu/20060929/lo_wdsu/9956336 Pink Taco Wants Naming Rights to Superdome]." ''[[WDSU]].'' September 28, 2006. Retrieved on September 29, 2006.</ref>
==Live animal controversy== On May 5, 2011 in honor of Cinco de Mayo the Pink Taco in Century City, CA painted a donkey pink and wrote "Pink Taco" on both its sides. Critics claimed the donkey was shaved, painted pink and left outside in 90 Â°[[Fahrenheit|F]] heat. Spokesman for the animal rental company said the animal was treated fairly and two trainers were on site to care for it. The restaurant manager refused to comment. <ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ktla.com/news/landing/ktla-pink-taco-donkey-outrage,0,7749811.story |title=Pink Taco Restaurant: Angry Community Members Call for Boycott Over Pink Taco's Pink Donkey Display for Cinco de Mayo - ktla.com |author=klta news|work=ktla.com |year=2011 |accessdate=9 May 2011}}</ref>
